newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Oct 25.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Oct 25.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- A key investigator of a land scandal in the northeastern province of Nong Khai claims to have strong evidence that the prime minister pressured the police department to go easy on the Tancharoen family, who was allegedly involved in the scandal. Pol Col Paitoon Wikiniyathani made the allegation following his unexpected transfer to Bangkok from Nong Khai, where he had served as deputy provincial police chief. (THE NATION) (BANGKOK POST)

- Defence Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh is quietly pushing his military satellite project months after saying it had been shelved. Chavalit has ordered a senior army officer to proceed with the so-called Star of Siam project on a confidential basis. (BANGKOK POST)

- A special committee has been set up to work out penalties to be imposed on illegal users of mobile phone signals. Presently, there is nothing the police can do if a legitimate mobile phone user lodges a complaint. (THE NATION)
- Pollution has reached a critical point in Bangkok, with dust particles registering 50 to 100 percet above the safety threshold, the Health Department said. (BANGKOK POST)

- Caltex Oil (Thailand) Ltd has unveiled a five billion baht, three-year improvement programme to rebuild and redecorate nearly 600 Caltex service stations nationwide in a major effort to raise standards, image and performance. (KRUNG THEP THURAKIJ)

- The Bank of Thailand has given banks and finance and securities companies until Oct 31 to apply for primary dealerships to trade bonds and securities through its open market operations. The move seen to represent a tangible effort by the central bank to develop its open market operations, which will not only improve its management of the country's liquidity but also set a benchmark for interest rates in the money market. (THE NATION)

- Former finance minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda vowed to restore investor confidence, regain economic potential and establish an effective action plan for the future if his Democrat party wins the November 17 election. (BUSINESS DAY)
